title: Why Object-Oriented Programming?

syntaxBreakdown.explanation: Defines a blueprint. By convention, class names use PascalCase (first letter capitalized). This is the template!
A FIELD - data stored in the class. 'public' means accessible from outside. Each object gets its OWN copy of this data!
Creates an OBJECT (instance) from the class blueprint. 'new' allocates memory and builds the object. This is called INSTANTIATION.
Dot notation accesses an object's data or methods. alice.Name gets Alice's name, bob.Name gets Bob's - they're separate!

challenge.instructions:
Create your first class!

1. Create a class called 'Car' with public fields:
   - string Brand
   - string Model
   - int Year
2. Create two Car objects:
   - One for a Toyota Camry from 2020
   - One for a Honda Civic from 2019
3. Display both cars in format: '[Brand] [Model] ([Year])'

This is your first step into OOP!

challenge.hint: Define class: class Car { public string Brand; ... }. Create object: Car c = new Car(); Set fields: c.Brand = 'Toyota';
commonStickingPoints: Forgetting 'new' keyword: Car c = Car(); is WRONG! Must be: Car c = new Car(); to create an object.
Class vs Object confusion: The class is the BLUEPRINT. Objects are INSTANCES built from the blueprint. You can have many objects from one class!
Forgetting 'public': If you don't write 'public', fields are private by default and can't be accessed outside the class!
Capitalization: Class names should be PascalCase (Player, Car, not player, car). This is convention, not a requirement, but follow it!
